page.title: Global silver trade from the 16th to 18th centuries

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{more citations needed|date=April 2015}} {{Essay-like|date=April 2015}} {{more footnotes|date=May 2015}} }} The '''global silver trade''' between the Americas and [[Europe]] from the sixteenth to nineteenth centuries was a spillover of the [[Columbian Exchange]] which had a profound effect on the world economy. In fact, many scholars consider the [[silver]] trade to mark the beginning of a genuinely [[global economy]], with one historian noting that silver "went round the world and made the world go round."<ref>{{Cite book|title=ReOrient: Global Economy in the Asian Age|last=Frank|first=Andre G.|publisher=University of California Press|year=1998|isbn=|location=Berkeley|pages=131}}</ref> Although global, much of that silver ended up in the hands of the Chinese, as they accepted it as a form of currency.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=von Glahn|first=Richard|date=1996|title=Myth and Reality of China’s Seventeenth Century Monetary Crisis|url=|journal=Journal of Economic History|volume=2|pages=132|quote=... silver wanders throughout all the world... before flocking to China, where it remains as if at its natural center.|via=}}</ref> In addition to the global economic changes the silver trade engendered, it also put into motion a wide array of political transformations in the early modern era. "New World mines," concluded several prominent historians "supported the Spanish empire," acting as a linchpin of the Spanish economy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Flynn|first=Dennis O.|last2=Giraldez|first2=Arturo|date=1995|title=Born with a 'Silver Spoon'|url=|journal=Journal of World History|volume=2|pages=210|via=}}</ref>
Spaniards at the time of the [[Age of Discovery|Age of Exploration]] discovered vast amounts of silver, much of which was from the [[Potosí]] silver mines, to fuel their trade economy. Potosí's deposits were rich and Spanish American silver mines were the world's cheapest sources of it. The Spanish acquired the silver, minting it into the peso de ocho (a currency) to then use it as a means of purchase; that currency was so widespread that even the United States accepted it as valid until the [[Coinage Act of 1857]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsl&fileName=011/llsl011.db&recNum=184|title=A Century of Lawmaking|last=|first=|date=|website=Library of Congress|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 23, 2018}}</ref> As the Spanish need for silver increased, new innovations for more efficient extraction of silver were developed, such as the amalgamation method of using [[mercury (element)|mercury]] to extract silver from ore.<ref name=":5" />
In the two centuries that followed the discovery of Potosí, the Spanish silver mines in the Americas produced 40,000 tons of silver.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Silver, Trade, and War: Spain and America in the Making of Early Modern Europe|last=Stein|first=Stanley J.|last2=Stein|first2=Barbara H.|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|year=2000|isbn=|location=|pages=21}}</ref> Altogether, more than 150,000 tons of silver were shipped from Potosí by the end of the 18th century.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.atlasobscura.com/places/potosi-silver-mines|title=Potosí Silver Mines|website=Atlas Obscura|access-date=2016-05-08}}</ref> From 1500 to 1800, Mexico and Peru produced about 80%<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Flynn|first=Dennis O.|date=1995|title=Born with a "Silver Spoon": The Origin of World Trade in 1571|url=http://www.uhpress.hawaii.edu/journals/jwh/jwh062p201.pdf|journal=Journal of World History|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> of the world's silver with 30% of it eventually ending up in China (largely because of British merchants who used it to purchase exotic Chinese commodities). In the late 16th and early 17th century, Japan was also exporting heavily into China and the foreign trade at large.<ref name=":0" />
As has been demonstrated, China dominated silver imports. The market value of silver in the [[Ming dynasty|Ming]] territory was double its value elsewhere, which provided great arbitrage profit for the Europeans and Japanese.<ref name=":0" /> The abundance of silver in China made it easy for the country to mint it into coinage. That process was so widespread that local Chinese government officials would demand taxes to be paid in silver to the point that silver eventually backed all of [[China's economy]].
==First paper money== The world's first [[paper money]] ("[[flying money]]") was invented by the Chinese<ref>{{Cite book|title=History of the Weksel: Bill of Exchange and Promissory Note|last=Moshenskyi|first=Sergii|publisher=Xlibris|year=2008|isbn=|location=|pages=50}}</ref> and they needed some commodity to back it. Traditional coins were useful, but the amount of coins needed for large purchases could be bulky and dangerous to transport. That problem was solved when the Chinese created small pieces of paper with pictures of the coin printed on them.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The History of Money|last=Weatherford|first=Jack|publisher=Crown Business|year=1997|isbn=|location=|pages=125–6}}</ref> By the nature of their geography, China had no real amount of precious metals of their own to back the paper money they invented. Because the Spaniards didn't find gold but did find copious amounts of silver, the Spaniards and the rest of Europe used this silver to purchase the commodities of choice from China, solving both of their problems.<ref name="columbia1">{{cite web|url=http://afe.easia.columbia.edu/chinawh/web/s5/s5_4.html |title=China and Europe, 1500–2000 and Beyond: What is Modern? |publisher=Afe.easia.columbia.edu |date= |accessdate=2015-03-30}}</ref>
== Silver in the Americas == [[File:Philip V Coin silver, 8 Reales Mexico.jpg|thumb|Silver Peso of Philip V]] A result of the [[Spanish colonization of the Americas]] was the discovery, production, and trade of precious metals. The Spanish, along with other European nations, had a great desire for Chinese goods such as [[silk industry in China|silk]] and [[porcelain]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Flynn|first=Dennis O.|last2=Giráldez|first2=Arturo|date=1995|title=Born with a "Silver Spoon": The Origin of World Trade in 1571|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/20078638|journal=Journal of World History|volume=6|issue=2|pages=201–221}}</ref> The Europeans did not have any goods or commodities which China desired, so they traded silver to make up for their trade deficit.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Reorient|last=Frank|first=Andre|publisher=|year=July 1998|isbn=9780520214743|location=|pages=}}</ref> The two most important mining colonies of the [[Spanish Empire]] were Peru and Mexico, who were estimated to have provided one-hundred thousand tons of silver from the mid 16th Century to the end of the colonial period.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Garner|first=Richard L.|date=1988|title=Long-Term Silver Mining Trends in Spanish America: A Comparative Analysis of Peru and Mexico|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/1863529|journal=The American Historical Review|volume=93|issue=4|pages=898–935|doi=10.2307/1863529}}</ref> The richest, and most productive mine in the Americas was that of [[Potosí]] in what is modern day Bolivia.<ref name=":4" /> The richest camp in Mexico was in the city of Zacatecas, however the production of this mine was far less than that of Potosi.<ref name=":4" />
=== Mining Processes in the Americas === More simplistic native mining techniques dominated American mining for the early part of the 16th Century.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Brading|first=D. A.|last2=Cross|first2=Harry E.|date=1972|title=Colonial Silver Mining: Mexico and Peru|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/2512781|journal=The Hispanic American Historical Review|volume=52|issue=4|pages=545–579|doi=10.2307/2512781}}</ref> Mining in the Americas became formally industrialized when the process of mercury amalgamation became popularized. Mercury amalgamation was invented by a Spaniard in central Mexico in the 1550s.<ref name=":5" /> Historians dispute what individual was the first to invent the process, however most agree that it was a Spaniard. Mercury was the one of the highest costs of production for the Americas, since much of it had to be shipped.<ref name=":4" /> The ratio of Mercury to silver produced was about two to one.<ref name=":4" /> Furthermore, German miners introduced the [[stamp mill]] and [[lead smelting]] in the 1530s.<ref name=":5" /> Gunpowder was often used to blast of large holes to create the mine shafts, although there were not many deep shafts.<ref name=":5" /> Potosí had the most amount of ore, however it was lower quality than that of Mexico.
Mining production in the Americas largely depended on native labor in both Mexico and Peru.<ref name=":5" /> In Mexico, many of the natives worked as wage laborers by the middle of the 17th Century.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/48249030|title=Mexico : from the beginning to the Spanish Conquest|last=1946-|first=Knight, Alan,|date=2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=052181474X|location=Cambridge, UK|oclc=48249030}}</ref> However, the labor system known as the [[repartimiento]] still existed in some places.<ref name=":6" /> Silver production in Mexico was relatively cheap when compared to that of Peru, and the general trend of Mexican labor systems was that towards waged labor.<ref name=":4" /> In Peru mines, the [[Mit'a|mit'a system]] was a dominant form of native labor subjection, although waged laborers worked on the mines as well.<ref name=":4" /> Natives under the mit'a system were paid much less, and this was necessary for the production of silver to continue in Peru where costs were relatively high.<ref name=":4" />
== Global Flow of Silver == The ultimate destination for the mass amounts of silver produced in the Americas and Japan was China.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Flynn|first=Dennis O.|last2=Giráldez|first2=Arturo|date=2002|title=Cycles of Silver: Global Economic Unity through the Mid-Eighteenth Century|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/20078977|journal=Journal of World History|volume=13|issue=2|pages=391–427}}</ref> Silver from the Americas flowed mostly across the Atlantic and made its way to the far east.<ref name=":3" /> A popular route was around the Cape of Good Hope into the east, and sometimes it came over land.<ref name=":3" /> Major outposts for the silver trade were located in Southeast Asian countries, such as the Philippines.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Flynn|first=Dennis O.|last2=Giraldez|first2=Arturo|date=1996|title=Silk for Silver: Manila-Macao Trade in the 17th Century|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/42634185|journal=Philippine Studies|volume=44|issue=1|pages=52–68}}</ref> The city of Manilla served as a primary outpost of the exchange of goods between the Americas, Japan, and China.<ref name=":8" /> However, there is a large amount of silver that crossed across the Pacific Ocean directly from the Americas as well.<ref name=":7" /> There are not many records of the amount of silver which crossed the Pacific due to it being discouraged by the [[Monarchy of Spain|Spanish monarchy]], so estimates highly vary.<ref name=":6" />
Silver also found its way across other parts of the world as well. India and Europe both received a fair amount of silver.<ref name=":3" /> This silver was often locally traded for other commodities, such as gold or crops. In India, silver flowed from the south to the north, and gold flowed the opposite way.<ref name=":3" /> Often silver and gold were manufactured into jewelry or hoarded as treasure.
=== China and the Demand for Silver === China was the ultimate destination in which silver would flow towards. In exchange, the Chinese traded their popular goods such as [[silk]] and [[porcelain]]. China had a high demand for silver due to its shift from paper money to coins in the early period of the Ming Dynasty.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=von Glahn|first=Richard|date=1996|title=Myth and Reality of China's Seventeenth-Century Monetary Crisis|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/2123972|journal=The Journal of Economic History|volume=56|issue=2|pages=429–454}}</ref> The Ming paper currency eventually failed due to self-imposed inflation along with an inability to stop the production of counterfeit bills.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chen|first=Shikuan|date=|title=The Sung and Ming Paper Monies: Currency Competition and Currency Bubbles|url=|journal=National Taiwan University|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The Ming attempted to produce copper coins as a new form of currency, but production was inconsistent.<ref name=":9" /> Hence silver became of high value because it was a valid currency that could be processed abroad. The bimetallic ratio of silver to gold was about two to one, which meant that European and Japanese merchants made a large amount of profit.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Atwell|first=William S.|date=2005|title=Another Look at Silver Imports into China, ca. 1635-1644|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/20079347|journal=Journal of World History|volume=16|issue=4|pages=467–489}}</ref> In the 1640s, the bimetallic ratios in China converged with the rest of the world, before experiencing another population boom.<ref name=":7" /> The new population boom was a product of the introduction of New World crops into China, mainly sweet potatoes, which could be more easily grown.<ref name=":7" /> By this time, the silver mines in Japan were largely depleted and the New World became China's primary source for silver.<ref name=":8" />
Initially, Japan served as China's primary source for silver in the 16th Century.<ref name=":2" /> In exchange for silver, China would provide Japan with silk and gold.<ref name=":8" /> Japan and China did not directly trade with each other, due to political tensions.<ref name=":8" /> This meant that European entities and countries, such as the Dutch and Portuguese served as a middle man between the two countries.<ref name=":8" />
=== China's Silver Dominance === In the famed ''[[The Wealth of Nations]],'' [[Adam Smith]] noted the sheer force and great reach of the global silver trade. He was impressed by its market value but more intrigued with the way this single item of commerce brought together new and old worlds i.e. the Americas and China.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/53006965|title=The wealth of nations|last=1723-1790.|first=Smith, Adam,|date=2003|publisher=Bantam Classic|others=Cannan, Edwin, 1861-1935.|isbn=0553585975|edition=Bantam classic|location=New York, N.Y.|oclc=53006965}}</ref> Although China acted as the cog running the wheel of global trade, Japan's huge contribution of silver exports to China were critical to the world economy and China's liquidity and success with the commodity. Historians posit Europeans would have been left out of world trade, and China may have fallen prey to conquest by settlers of the Americas if not for Japanese silver mining. Silver was paramount to East Asia's introduction into the global trade market.<ref name="Flynn 2002 391–427">{{Cite journal|last=Flynn|first=Dennis Owen|last2=Giraldez|first2=Arturo|date=2002|title=Cycles of Silver: Global Economic Unity through the Mid-Eighteenth Century|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1353/jwh.2002.0035|journal=Journal of World History|volume=13|issue=2|pages=391–427|doi=10.1353/jwh.2002.0035|issn=1527-8050}}</ref> Under the [[Ming dynasty|Ming]] and [[Qing dynasty|Qing]] empires, China hoarded silver to boost its economy and increase its trading power.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Southeast Asia in the Early Modern Era Trade, Power, and Belief.|last=Reid|first=Anthony J.S.|publisher=Cornell University Press|year=1993|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
Many historians argue that silver was responsible for the birth of global economics and trade. According to this view, global trade commenced in 1571 when [[Manila]] was founded and became the first trading post linking America and Asia due to the expansive and profitable silver trade.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Flynn|first=Dennis|last2=Giraldez|first2=Arturo|date=1995-01-01|title=Arbitrage, China, and World Trade in the Early Modern Period|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/1568520952600308|journal=Journal of the Economic and Social History of the Orient|volume=38|issue=4|pages=429–448|doi=10.1163/1568520952600308|issn=0022-4995}}</ref> In fact, research shows the amount of silver traveling from Manila to China was approximately three million [[peso]]s or 94,000 kilograms in the early 1600s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Atwell, wen-t'i|first=William S., Ch'ing-shih|date=December 1977|title=Notes on Silver, Foreign Trade, and the Late Ming Economy|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/398568|journal=3|volume=|pages=1–33|via=}}</ref>
The rarity of silver production was seen as an opportunity for China to control the currency's value and support its own national currency. Silver was one of the only accepted trade items from Europeans and its value in China was astronomical compared to rest of the world. In fact, its value was twice that of [[Spain]] in the 16th and 17th centuries.<ref name="Flynn 2002 391–427"/> Between 1600 and 1800 China received 100 tons of silver on average per year. A large populace near the [[Yangtze River Delta|Lower Yangzte]] averaged a hundreds of [[tael]]s of silver per household in the late 16th century.<ref>{{Citation|last=Huang|first=Ray|title=Financial management|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/cbo9780511735400.011|work=Taxation and Governmental Finance in Sixteenth-Century Ming China|pages=266–305|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780511735400|access-date=2018-07-26}}</ref>
Silver even played a large role when defending [[Toyotomi Hideyoshi]]'s attemptive take over of Ming ruled [[Joseon|Joseon Korea]]. The Ming Ministiry of War sent approximately 140,000 liang of silver to its soldiers and required provinces to provide silver as tax for the war effort as well.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/843883049|title=A dragon's head and a serpent's tail : Ming China and the first great East Asian war, 1592-1598|last=Kenneth.|first=Swope,|date=2009|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=9780806185026|location=Norman|oclc=843883049}}</ref> In the sixteenth century, the [[Daimyō|daimyos]] of Southwest Japan hoped for unhinged global trade but were stopped due to Ming China trade policies. Still, Japan became a player in the global economy via frequent Ming merchant ships arriving to extract Japan's abundance of silver and exchange goods. Japan increased its wealth through successful trilateral trade with [[Portugal]] and China as Japan now had Chinese goods to offer the Portuguese who had silver mines of their own.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kobata|first=A.|date=1965|title=The Production and Uses of Gold and Silver in Sixteenth- and Seventeenth-Century Japan|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2307/2592093|journal=The Economic History Review|volume=18|issue=2|pages=245|doi=10.2307/2592093|issn=0013-0117}}</ref> Founder of the Ming China dynasty, [[Hongwu Emperor|Hongwu,]] actually sought to eliminate silver from the market due to his fear of inflation which he previously experienced in the [[Yuan dynasty|Yuan]] dynasty. His attempt involved imposing harsh limits on silver mining to stop its flow into the market and subsequently replaced it with baochao or paper money. However, the currency never popularized and silver proved its mainstay as a global currency.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McDermott|first=Joseph P.|last2=Brook|first2=Timothy|date=1999|title=The Confusions of Pleasure: Commerce and Culture in Ming China|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2307/2672136|journal=Pacific Affairs|volume=72|issue=2|pages=267|doi=10.2307/2672136|issn=0030-851X}}</ref>
==Opium Wars== {{Main|Opium Wars}} Despite some restrictions, silver continued to drive trade through its popularity in Europe. This, combined with a high British demand for [[Chinese tea]], created chronic trade deficits for European governments, which were forced to risk silver deficits to supply merchants in Asia.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=The Immobile Empire—The first great collision of East and West—the astonishing history of Britain's grand, ill-fated expedition to open China to Western Trade, 1792–94|last=Peyrefitte|first=Alain|publisher=Alfred A. Knopf|year=1992|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> As supplies of silver decreased in Europe, Europeans had less ability to purchase highly coveted Chinese goods. Merchants were no longer able to sustain the China trade through profits made by selling Chinese goods in the West and were forced to take bullion out of circulation in Europe to buy goods in China.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Rebellions and Revolutions: China from the 1800s to 2000|last=Gray|first=Jack|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2002|isbn=|location=New York|pages=22–3}}</ref>
In the 19th century, American merchants began to introduce opium to Chinese markets. The demand for opium rose rapidly and was so profitable that Chinese opium dealers began to seek out more suppliers of the drug, thus inaugurating the opium trade; one merchant declared that Opium "is like gold. It can sell any time."<ref name=":1" /> From 1804 to 1820, a period when the Qing Dynasty needed to finance the suppression of the [[White Lotus Rebellion]], Chinese merchants were soon exporting silver to pay for opium rather than Europeans paying for Chinese goods with the precious metal.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Voyage of the 'Frolic': New England Merchants and the Opium Trade|last=Layton|first=Thomas N.|publisher=Stanford University Press|year=1997|isbn=|location=|pages=28}}</ref>
The Qing imperial court debated whether and how to end the opium trade, eventually settling on regulations on consumption. That measure, however, resulted in an increase in drug smuggling by Europeans and Chinese traders. In 1810, the Daoguang Emperor issued an edict concerning the matter, declaring, "Opium has a harm. Opium is a poison, undermining our good customs and morality. Its use is prohibited by law."<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Documentary Chronicle of Sino-Western relations|last=Fu|first=Lo-shu|publisher=|year=1966|isbn=|volume=1|location=|pages=380}}</ref> Following a debate at court in 1836 on whether to legalize the drug or crack down on its use, the emperor decided on the latter. An upright official, Commissioner Lin Zexu led the campaign against opium as a kind of "drug czar." The British, offended by the seizure of their property in opium, sent a large naval expedition to China to end the restrictive conditions under which they had long traded with that country. Thus began the first Opium War, in which Britain's industrialized military might was proven in China's rout. The [[Treaty of Nanking]], which ended the war in 1842 largely on British terms, imposed numerous restrictions on Chinese sovereignty and opened five ports to European traders.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Taking of Hong Kong: Charles and Clara Elliot in China Waters|last=Hoe|first=Susanna|last2=Roebuck|first2=Derek|publisher=Routledge|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=203}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=May 2014}} '''Global studies''' is the [[interdisciplinary]] study of [[political]], [[economic]], [[legal]], [[ecological]] and [[cultural]] interconnectedness. Predominant subjects are [[politics]], [[economics]] and [[law]] on an international level. Global studies is oriented around the study of [[globalization]] as it relates to intercontinental politics, the global economy, international law, market relations, the movement of people and resources, global communications, the effect of human activity on the environment, and many more topics. Global studies is often used to map global change and is both [[Microeconomics|micro]] and [[Macroeconomics|macro]] in scope. The Cambridge English Dictionary defines global studies as ''"the study of political, economic, and social situations in the world"''.{{cite web|title=Cambridge English Dictionary: Global Studies|url=https://dictionary.cambridge.org/de/worterbuch/englisch/global-studies}} Global studies tackles the aforementioned topics by examining global power structures influenced by perspectives such as [[Orientalism]] and [[Eurocentrism]]. Global studies is distinguished from international studies by its broader focus – [[international studies]] is only one aspect of global studies. In cases such as international studies or [[international relations]], the concept of 'national' confines the meaning of those fields of study. By comparison, global studies has a broader reach, from the global to the local. == History and context == {{See also|Globalization}} The development of global studies in secondary and tertiary education is arguably a product of globalization, and its consequent results on the international community. In the late 20th century, an unprecedented rise in communications technologies and computerization occurred around the world, again enhancing the processes of globalization: “it is a shift in our very life circumstances ... the speed of change is closely allied to the growth of communication, and development in information and communication technologies have been exponential ... globalization is a fact of life from which we cannot retreat.”.{{Cite book|title=The consequences of modernity|last=Giddens|first=Anthony|publisher=|year=1990|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}} As a result of this constantly changing global community, education providers began to see a need for the introduction of global studies into secondary school curricula (i.e. introduction of [[global issues]] through already existing subjects), and to create global studies degrees for tertiary students (i.e. sole degrees with a global focus). According to Jan Nederveen Pieterse, Mellichamp Professor of Global Studies and Sociology at The University of California, Santa Barbara:
The first Global Studies conference took place at the University of Illinois Chicago in 2008; the 2009 conference was held in Dubai on the theme Views from Dubai: The Gulf and Globalization. The 2010 conference was in Busan, South Korea under the heading Global Rebalancing: East Asia and Globalization; the 2011 conference took place in Rio de Janeiro on Emerging societies and Emancipation; the 2012 conference was at Moscow University on the theme of Eurasia and Globalization: Complexity and Global studies; and the 2013 conference took place in New Delhi on the theme of Social Development in South Asia.{{Cite web|url=http://onglobalization.com/assets/downloads/global/E14FinalProgram.pdf|title=Seventh Global Studies Conference Program|last=|first=|date=|website=onglobalization.com|publisher=|access-date=}}
The Global Studies Journal was founded in 2008 and is "devoted to mapping and interpreting new trends and patterns in globalization".{{Cite web|url=http://onglobalization.com/journal|title=Journal – Global Studies Research Network|website=onglobalization.com|access-date=2016-11-29}} == Definitions of global studies == === Global vs. international studies === There can be much confusion about the use of the terms, "global studies" and "international studies." They are at times used interchangeably and differences in meaning are not evident, however, both disciplines are concerned with political, social and cultural issues, with the main focus of study being placed on international community interaction. However, subtle distinctions can be made between the two phrases. International studies generally looks at exchanges between states, multilateral or bilateral agreements, diplomacy and how issues are handled between two or more states. Global studies, in contrast, focuses on globally shared issues.{{cite web|url=http://globalstudies.unc.edu/masters/|accessdate=2016-11-29}} It has also been suggested that there are [[left wing]] and [[right wing]] connotations to each phrase, international studies being preferred by the right wing (i.e. relations between states) and global studies preferred by the left (i.e. issues affecting all global citizens).{{cite web|last1=Moravcsik|first1=Andrew|title=Liberal Theories of International Relations: A Primer|url=https://www.princeton.edu/~amoravcs/publications.html|website=princeton.edu|accessdate=2016-11-29}} The terms have also been described as such:
International studies might be called the grandfather of global education. It often includes the study of countries, world religions, languages and international relations ... (global studies) is centred on the concept of connectedness – recognizing local/ global connections, the commonalities all humans share, and how understanding how national borders have become practically irrelevant for many global actors.Merryfield, M 2004 ‘The importance of a global education,’ ''Outreach World'', viewed 5/10/10 at: http://www.outreachworld.org/article.asp?articleid=77 {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110207103229/http://outreachworld.org/article.asp?articleid=77 |date=2011-02-07 }}
=== Characteristics === Five defining characteristics of global studies were identified by scholars at the first annual meeting of the [[Global Studies Consortium]] in Tokyo in 2008:[[Mark Juergensmeyer]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=KXhfAgAAQBAJ&pg=PR14&lpg=PR14&dq=%22Global+Studies+Consortium%22+Conference+2008+Tokyo&source=bl&ots=kAnRbWAD4e&sig=3h2899QfrUezZ9coblAqlLLTUfs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj-5Izjj_HKAhVF7yYKHchxBpcQ6AEISDAJ#v=onepage&q=%22Global%20Studies%20Consortium%22%20Conference%202008%20Tokyo&f=false ''Thinking Globally: A Global Studies Reader''] * [[wikt:transnational|Transnational]] * [[Interdisciplinary]]: global studies scholarship can involve politics, economics, history, geography, anthropology, sociology, religion, technology, philosophy, health as well as the study of the environment, gender, and race. * [[Contemporary]] and [[historical]] examples range from the transnational activity of the Greek and Roman Empires to modern European colonialism. * [[Postcolonialism|Postcolonial]] and [[Critical theory|Critical]]: global studies often emphasizes a postcolonial perspective, and attempts to analyze global phenomena through a critical, multicultural lens. == Subjects of interest == The field of global studies revolves around the impacts of globalization and the growing interdependence of states, economies, societies, cultures, and people. This necessitates that students are well versed and capable of critical analysis when it comes to global issues."Global Education Policies and Practices," Peace Corps. {{cite web |url=http://peacecorpsconnect.org/global-education-policies-and-practices |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612210639/http://peacecorpsconnect.org/global-education-policies-and-practices |archivedate=2010-06-12 |df= }}, accessed September 7, 2009. Some of the most pressing issues in global studies are [[national security]] and [[diplomacy]], effective [[citizenship]] in a [[participatory democracy]], global [[competitiveness]] in a world market and the desire to enter the aid and development sector. === National security === The first major funding for international education was the 1966 International Education Act in the US. It provided funding to institutions of higher education to create and strengthen international studies programs."Digest for Education Statistics, 2004 – Chapter 4: Federal Programs for Education and Related Activities." National Center for Education Statistics (2004), http://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d04/ch_4.asp, accessed September 7, 2009. Created at the time of the [[Cold War]], this act stressed the need for all citizens (with a focus on USA citizens) to understand global issues in order to build skills for diplomacy.International Education Act: Hearings Before the Subcommittee on Education of the Committee on Labor and Public Welfare, United States Senate, Eighty-Ninth Congress, Second Session on S. 2874 and H.R. 14643. Publication date: 1966, Accessed through ERIC, http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/custom/portlets/recordDetails/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=ED093756&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=ED093756.”The importance of diplomacy as a driving force for political development is well known and understood. It is of great importance as a long term instrument for conflict prevention.”Skylakakis, T 2010, ‘The importance of economic diplomacy,’ The Bridge Magazine, viewed 24/9/10 at: http://www.bridgemag.com/magazine/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=81&Itemid=38 The development of issues and crisis on a global scale such as international terrorism, climate change and environmental degradation, pandemics (such as ebola), and the [[Great Recession]] have convinced policymakers of the importance of global studies and international education to national security and diplomacy.Korry, Elaine. "Bush Expected to Hike Funding for Language Training," National Public Radio Broadcast, January 5, 2006, Accessed online https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5127944 === Global economy === A second motivation for global studies is facilitating a better understanding of the [[global marketplace]]. Many international companies have identified the need for a workforce that has the skills to work cross-culturally and identify and serve the needs of a global market.Groennings, Sven. "Economic Competitiveness and International Knowledge. A Regional Project on the Global Economy and Higher Education in New England. Staff Paper II." New England Board of Higher Education. October 28, 1987. p. 26 Some international companies, such as Microsoft, have taken the lead in convening policymakers and key stakeholders to demand additional investment in education."ECS, ISTE and [[Microsoft]] to Sponsor Global Education Competitiveness Summit." http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/press/2009/jun09/06-23gecs2009nrpr.mspx, Accessed September 8, 2009. The US state and federal governments have also placed global studies as a key priority for preparing a competitive workforce.Putting the World into World Class Education. West Virginia Department of Education. http://wvconnections.k12.wv.us/documents/GlobalAwarenessPresentation062408_001.ppt, Accessed September 8, 2009 Furthermore, in 2002 the Australian federal government (through its development body AusAID) used some of its funding to introduce a ‘Global Education Program.’ This program aims to increase understanding of development and international issues among Australian students. It provides teachers with professional development opportunities with NGOs and thorough curriculum support. The program “informs and encourages teachers to introduce students to global issues in a classroom setting.”Gallus, C 2002 ‘Global Studies Statement Launch,” AusAID, viewed 2/10/10 at: {{cite web |url=http://www.ausaid.gov.au/media/release.cfm?BC=Speech&ID=9768_9422_1276_9667_8426 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100923153626/http://ausaid.gov.au/media/release.cfm?BC=Speech&ID=9768_9422_1276_9667_8426 |archivedate=2010-09-23 |df= }} Higher education institutions have closely followed with integrating international studies across disciplines. It is rare to find a leading business school without an international focus.Harvard Business School. http://www.hbs.edu/global/, Accessed September 8, 2009Yale Business School. http://mba.yale.edu/MBA/curriculum/core/international.shtml {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090925054608/http://mba.yale.edu/MBA/curriculum/core/international.shtml |date=2009-09-25 }}, Accessed September 8, 2009. === Global citizenship and rights === A third motivation for global studies is the creation of an effective citizenry. In the US, the National Council of Social Studies states that the purpose of social studies is to “teach students the content knowledge, intellectual skills, and civic values necessary for fulfilling the duties of citizenship in a participatory democracy.” A key goal of the NCSS is “global education”."About National Council for the Social Studies." The National Council for Social Studies, http://www.socialstudies.org/about, Accessed September 8, 2009 As globalization causes the lines between national and international to become blurred, it becomes increasingly important for citizens to understand global relationships.Lapayese, Yvette. "Review:Toward a Critical Global Studies Education" Comparative Education Review, Vol. 47, No. 4 (Nov., 2003), pp. 493–501 The creation of effective [[Global citizenship]] results in people who are willing to, and have the capacity to become involved in local and global issues. In the UK, local government research conducted in the surrounding areas of London has found that citizens must have the opportunity to become involved and then possess the skill, knowledge and confidence to take part. The outcomes are often very positive, leading to an improvement in services, better quality of democratic participation and community education.Andrews, Cowell, Downe, Martin 2006 ‘Promoting effective citizenship and community empowerment,’ Office of the Deputy PM, London, viewed at: {{cite web |url=http://www.cdhn.org/documentbank/uploads/PromotingEffectiveCitizenship.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725151250/http://www.cdhn.org/documentbank/uploads/PromotingEffectiveCitizenship.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }} To achieve effective citizenship, students must be educated in ways that engage and place emphasis on the importance of global issues. By studying a subject such as global studies, students can gain the knowledge required to become effective citizens. Some critical scholars note that beyond content, students must be taught "global cognition" in order to truly understand global perspectives. These scholars believe that in order to fully understand world issues, students must recognize that their perspective is not necessarily shared by others and understand the social forces that influence their views.Hanvey, Robert. "An Attainable Global Perspective." Theory into Practice, Vol. 21, No. 3, Global Education (Summer, 1982), pp. 162–67Anderson, Charlotte. "Global Education in the Classroom." Theory into Practice, Vol. 21, No. 3, Global Education (Summer, 1982), pp. 168–76 These perspectives encourage engagement with new promises and threats for the promotion of human rights, social justice, and political participation. === International Institutions === By 2006, the international development sector had expanded exponentially, with the “NGO sector now being the 8th largest economy in the world ... employing nearly 19 million paid workers."Hall-Jones, P 2006, ‘The rise and rise of NGOs,’ Public Services International, viewed 23/9/10 at: http://www.world-psi.org/Template.cfm?Section=Home&CONTENTID=11738&TEMPLATE=/ContentManagement/ContentDisplay.cfm {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727122306/http://www.world-psi.org/Template.cfm?Section=Home&CONTENTID=11738&TEMPLATE=%2FContentManagement%2FContentDisplay.cfm |date=2011-07-27 }} Financing health projects used to be the biggest issue in global aid, but private and public organizations like the [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]] have helped overcome such problems. The issue now is making sure that the money is used in a proper manner to help those in need of the primary essentials of life.Garrett, Laurie. 2007. "The Challenge of Global Health," ''Foreign Affairs'' '''86''' (1):14-38. Studying global studies may lead to involvement in the aid and [[International development|development]] sector in multiple ways. These can include working in post-conflict or natural disaster zones, improving public services in developing communities (health, education, infrastructure, agriculture) or aiding private sector growth through business and market models.Coffey International Development, 2010 ‘Work that makes a difference,’ Coffey, viewed 24/9/10 at: http://www.coffey.com/our-businesses/coffey-international-development/our-expertise/sectors/overview{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Through studying global studies, students can be equipped with cross cultural knowledge, field experience and an awareness of global issues. Many students are now studying global studies in order to enter this sector. == Learning outcomes and job prospects == Learning outcomes for global studies vary depending on the institutes curriculum and students individual focuses. Although, introductory courses are designed to cover a wide range of topics in a single semester, students are expected to delve into a specific phenomenon or area of study for their academic career. there are some generic outcomes that students are expected to develop over the duration of study. These include, but are not limited to: *Cultural awareness *Ability to analyze the interconnectedness of the global and local *Skills in ethical research and analysis with specific policy implications *Awareness of current affairs *Ability to communicate effectively in a range of situations *Increase in cross cultural competence *potentially improve proficiency in a foreign language Global studies scholars are eligible for a myriad of professions, tackling political, social, and economic issues on an international scale that work to improve the human condition. *International relations *Foreign affairs *NGOs *Local, national, and international government *Environmental research *Historical Analysis == Universities that offer global studies == {{external links|section|date=May 2014}} {{div This is a category of disclosures related to [[global surveillance]].
== Court orders, memos and policy documents == *[[:File:Israel Morandum of Understanding SIGINT.pdf|Memorandum of understanding between the NSA and the Israel SIGINT National Unit (ISNU)]] *April 2013 FISC Order demanding that Verizon hand over all telephony metadata to NSA. The order had been initially granted in May 2006. In 2009 the FISC discovered that the government had made repeated and substantial misrepresentations to the court about its use, and had routinely been "running queries of the metadata using querying terms that did not meet the required standard for querying." It further concluded that the violations had been routine and systematic.<ref name="FiscPrivacyRuling2011a">{{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/sites/default/files/filenode/fisc_opinion_-_unconstitutional_surveillance_0.pdf|page=16|date=October 3, 2011|author=John D Bates|title=[redacted]}}</ref> *Legal Justification of the bulk telephony metadata collection (officially released)<ref name="IContheRecord1">{{cite web |url=http://icontherecord.tumblr.com/post/57514665466/dni-clapper-declassifies-and-releases-telephone|title=DNI Clapper Declassifies and Releases Telephone Metadata Collection Documents |date=July 31, 2013 |author=Turner, Shawn |accessdate=August 22, 2013}}</ref> *2009 NSA Procedures for Targeting Foreigners for Surveillance *2009 NSA Procedures for Minimizing collection on US Persons *2011 NSA Procedures for Minimizing collection on US Persons (officially released)<ref name="dni1">{{cite web|url=http://www.dni.gov/files/documents/Minimization%20Procedures%20used%20by%20NSA%20in%20Connection%20with%20FISA%20SECT%20702.pdf|title =Minimization Procedures Used by the National Security Agency in Connection with Acquisitions of Foreign Intelligence Information Pursuant to Section 702, as amended|date = October 31, 2011}}</ref> **Reference to a 2011 Change in the court-approved Minimization Procedures allowing analysts to run search queries using US persons' identifiers if there is "effective" oversight by NSA (it is not publicly known if such oversight has been established, or if any such searches have been conducted).<ref name="BallAckermanLoophole">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/09/nsa-loophole-warrantless-searches-email-calls |title=NSA loophole allows warrantless search for US citizens' emails and phone calls |author=James Ball and [[Spencer Ackerman]] |date=August 9, 2013 |accessdate=August 12, 2013}}</ref> The court order mentioned was later officially released.<ref name="FiscPrivacyRuling2011">{{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/sites/default/files/filenode/fisc_opinion_-_unconstitutional_surveillance_0.pdf|page=71|date=October 3, 2011|author=John D Bates|title=[redacted]}}</ref> <!--page 22 --> *October 2011 Court decision finding NSA's upstream collection program, which collected tens of thousands of non-target communications, to have violated the law. It held, citing multiple Supreme Court precedents, that the Fourth Amendment applies to the contents of all communications, whatever the means (they are "papers").<!-- ibid. pg 73-74 --> It also finds that the NSA's minimization and targeting policies to be legally and/or constitutionally deficient, and recommends changes. (officially released).<ref name=FiscPrivacyRuling2011/><ref name="Nakashima">{{cite news|last=Nakashima|first=Ellen|title=NSA gathered thousands of Americans' e-mails before court ordered it to revise its tactics|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-gathered-thousands-of-americans-e-mails-before-court-struck-down-program/2013/08/21/146ba4b6-0a90-11e3-b87c-476db8ac34cd_story.html|accessdate=September 16, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=August 21, 2013}}</ref><ref name="apps.washingtonpost.com">{{cite news|title=FISA court ruling on illegal NSA e-mail collection program|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/fisa-court-documents-on-illegal-nsa-e-mail-collection-program/409/|accessdate=September 16, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=August 21, 2013}}</ref><ref name="http">{{cite news|title=First direct evidence of illegal surveillance found by the FISA court|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/first-direct-evidence-of-illegal-surveillance-found-by-the-fisa-court/393/|accessdate=September 16, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=August 15, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}</ref><ref name="Charlie Savage and Scott Shane">{{cite news|title=Secret Court Rebuked N.S.A. on Surveillance|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/22/us/2011-ruling-found-an-nsa-program-unconstitutional.html?_r=3&&pagewanted=all|accessdate=September 16, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 21, 2013|author1=Charlie Savage |author2=Scott Shane }}</ref><ref name="Mark Hosenball and Tabassum Zakaria">{{cite web|title=NSA collected 56,000 emails by Americans a year: documents|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/technology/nsa-collected-56-000-emails-americans-year-documents-6C10975688|work=Reuters|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=September 16, 2013|author1=Mark Hosenball |author2=Tabassum Zakaria |date=August 22, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Perez|first=Evan|title=NSA misrepresented scope of data collection to secret court|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/08/21/politics/nsa-fisa-court|publisher=CNN|accessdate=October 2, 2013|date=August 22, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Turner|first=Shawn|title=DNI Declassifies Intelligence Community Documents Regarding Collection Under Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)|url=http://icontherecord.tumblr.com/post/58944252298/dni-declassifies-intelligence-community-documents|work=Office of the Director of National Intelligence|publisher=IC on the Record|accessdate=October 2, 2013|date=August 21, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Clapper|first=James|title=DNI James Clapper's Cover Letter Announcing the Document Release|url=http://www.dni.gov/files/documents/DNI%20Clapper%20Section%20702%20Declassification%20Cover%20Letter.pdf|publisher=Director of National Intelligence|accessdate=October 2, 2013|date=August 21, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=NSA Collected Thousands Of Emails, Other Communications By Americans With No Terror Ties|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/21/nsa-email-collection_n_3791459.html|agency=Associated Press|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=October 2, 2013|author1=Kimberly Dozier |author2=Stephen Braun |date=August 21, 2013}}</ref> Additional findings: **The collection of Upstream data had begun before a court order approving it, in violation of 50 USC § 1809(a), which makes it a crime to engage in, use or disseminate surveillance knowing, or having reason to know such surveillance was not authorized. <!-- ibid. pg 17, footnote 15 --><ref>{{cite news|last=Fung|first=Brian|title=The FISA court got really upset when the NSA didn't tell the truth on surveillance|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/08/21/the-fisa-court-got-really-upset-when-the-nsa-didnt-tell-the-truth-on-surveillance/|accessdate=September 16, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=August 21, 2013}}</ref> *March 2009 FISC ruling showing a consistent pattern of misrepresentations of the bulk telephone metadata collection program by the government to the Court. It also held that the data was being routinely queried in ways that did not meet "reasonable articulatable suspicion", demonstrating inadequate safeguards in the software and training of analysts. Showing that "thousands of violations resulted from the use of identifiers that were not "RAS-approved by analysts who were not even aware that they were accessing BR metadata," and that in 2006 "there was no single person [in the NSA] who had a complete understanding of the BR FISA system architecture," a situation which persisted until February 2009 or later. RAS is shorthand for Reasonable Articulatable Suspicion. The Court nonetheless reapproved the collection of bulk phone metadata, while mandating additional safeguards and training, and "end-to-end system engineering reviews," and reports from the review. (Officially released by court order)<ref name="wsjinforgraphic20130910">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324094704579067422990999360#project%3DNSAdocument0910%26articleTabs%3Darticle|title=NSA Violated Privacy Protections, Officials Say|author1=Siobhan Gorman |author2=Devlin Barrett |date=September 10, 2013|accessdate=September 10, 2013|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref><!--Quotes directly from the attached court order --><ref>{{cite news|last=Ackerman|first=Spencer|title=NSA violations led judge to consider viability of surveillance program|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/10/nsa-violated-court-rules-data-documents|accessdate=September 16, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=September 10, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Declassified court documents highlight NSA violations in data collection for surveillance|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/declassified-court-documents-highlight-nsa-violations/2013/09/10/60b5822c-1a4b-11e3-a628-7e6dde8f889d_story.html|accessdate=September 14, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=September 10, 2013|author1=Ellen Nakashima |author2=Julie Tate |author3=Carol Leonnig }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Declassified FISA court documents on intelligence collection|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/declassified-fisa-court-documents-on-intelligence-collection/447/|accessdate=September 14, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=September 10|author=Office of the Director of National Intelligence.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=DNI Clapper Declassifies Intelligence Community Documents Regarding Collection Under Section 501 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)|url=http://icontherecord.tumblr.com/post/60867560465/dni-clapper-declassifies-intelligence-community|work=Office of the Director of National Intelligence|publisher=IC On the Record|accessdate=September 14, 2013|author=James R. Clapper (Director of National Intelligence)|date=September 10, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Tim|first=Trevor|title=Government Releases NSA Surveillance Docs and Previously Secret FISA Court Opinions In Response to EFF Lawsuit|url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2013/09/government-releases-nsa-surveillance-docs-and-previously-secret-fisa-court|work=Electronic Frontier Foundation|publisher=Electronic Frontier Foundation|accessdate=September 14, 2013|date=September 10, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=NSA Illegally Gorged on U.S. Phone Records for Three Years|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2013/09/nsa-violations/|accessdate=September 22, 2013|newspaper=Wired.com|date=September 10, 2013|author1=David Kravets. Kim Zetter |author2=Kevin Poulsen }}</ref> *October 2012 [[Presidential Policy Directive 20]] (PPD20), outlining cyberwarfare. *2007 [[Michael Mukasey]] memo proposing broader powers. *April 2013 list of US Spying targets and topics by priority. The top priority countries are: Iran, Russia, China, Pakistan, North Korea and Afghanistan. Germany, France, the European Union, and Japan are mid-level priorities; Italy and Spain rank lower.<ref name="Spiegel2">{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/nsa-fuehrt-deutschland-als-spionageziel-a-915871.html|title= US-Geheimdienst: NSA führt Deutschland als Spionageziel|date=August 10, 2013|author=Staff}}</ref><ref name="DW1">{{cite news|url=http://dw.de/p/19NYt|date=August 11, 2008|author=Timothy Jones|title=Germany and EU targets for US espionage, Spiegel reports}}</ref> * FY 2013 Intelligence "Black Budget" Summary.<ref name="WaPo20130829">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/black-budget-summary-details-us-spy-networks-successes-failures-and-objectives/2013/08/29/7e57bb78-10ab-11e3-8cdd-bcdc09410972_story.html|title=U.S. spy network's successes, failures and objectives detailed in 'black budget' summary|authors=Barton Gellman and Greg Miller|date=August 29, 2013|accessdate=August 29, 2013|work=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref name="WaPo20130829C">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/special/national/black-budget/|title=The Black Budget|date=August 29, 2013|accessdate=August 29, 2013|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> * A memorandum of understanding concerning US sharing of raw [[SIGINT]] with Israel. The data has not been scrubbed to eliminate US persons, it asks Israel not to deliberately target US persons, however the agreement allows Israel to retain US person data for one full year. The memorandum is not legally binding. A separate document states "And there are other kinds of CI threats that are right on our midst. For example, one of NSA's biggest threats is actually from friendly intelligence services, like Israel.", it continues "Balancing the SIGINT exchange between US and Israeli needs has been a constant challenge. In the last decade, it arguably tilted heavily in favor of Israeli security concerns. 9/11 came and went, and with NSA's only true Third Party CT relationship being driven almost entirely driven by the needs of the partner."<ref name=guardianIsrael>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/11/nsa-americans-personal-data-israel-documents|title=NSA shares raw intelligence including Americans' data with Israel|authors=[[Glenn Greenwald]], [[Laura Poitras]], and [[Ewen MacAskill]]|date =September 11, 2013|accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> * September 13, 2013 FISC Court order declassifing all the legal opinions relating to Section 215 of the Patriot Act written after May 2011 not already the subject of Freedom of Information Act litigation. The FISA Court ruled that the White House must identify the opinions in question by October 4, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sailor IV|first=F. Dennis|title=United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court In Re Orders of this Court Interpreting Section 215 of the Patriot Act (Docket No. Misc. 13-02)|url=http://www.uscourts.gov/uscourts/courts/fisc/misc-13-02-order-130813.pdf|publisher=www.uscourts.gov|accessdate=September 15, 2013|date=September 13, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Fung|first=Brian|title=The FISA court will release more opinions because of Snowden|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/09/13/the-fisa-court-will-release-more-opinions-because-of-snowden/?tid=pm_business_pop|accessdate=September 15, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=September 13, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Ackerman|first=Spencer|title=Fisa judge: Snowden's NSA disclosures triggered important spying debate|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/13/edward-snowden-nsa-disclosures-judge|accessdate=September 16, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=September 13, 2013}}</ref> * 1,000 pages of documents were released by [[James R. Clapper Jr.]] on November 19, 2013 in response to lawsuits filed by the American Civil Liberties Union and the Electronic Frontier Foundation and a directive by U.S. President Barack Obama. |author2=Dan Roberts |date=16 December 2013}}</ref> and ordered the government to destroy any of their records that have been gathered. But the judge stayed action on his ruling pending a government appeal, recognizing in his 68-page opinion the "significant national security interests at stake in this case and the novelty of the constitutional issues."<ref name="WP20131216">{{cite news|title=Judge: NSA's collecting of phone records is probably unconstitutional|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/judge-nsas-collecting-of-phone-records-is-likely-unconstitutional/2013/12/16/6e098eda-6688-11e3-a0b9-249bbb34602c_story.html|accessdate=17 December 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=16 December 2013|author1=Ellen Nakashima |author2=Ann E. Marimow }}</ref> * 2013-12-27 ruling by U.S. District Judge William H. Pauley III in New York City holding<ref>{{cite web|last=Pauley III|first=William H.|title=United States District Court Southern District of New York: American Civil Liberties Union v. James R. Clapper (13 Civ. 3994) (WHP)|url=https://www.aclu.org/files/assets/order_granting_governments_motion_to_dismiss_and_denying_aclu_motion_for_preliminary_injunction.pdf|publisher=American Civil Liberties Union|accessdate=28 December 2013|date=27 December 2013}}</ref> the U.S. government's global telephone data-gathering system is needed to thwart potential terrorist attacks, and that it can only work if everyone's calls are swept in. In his opinion, he wrote, "a bulk telephony metadata collection program [is] a wide net that could find and isolate gossamer contacts among suspected terrorists in an ocean of seemingly disconnected data" and noted that a similar collection of data prior to 9/11 might have prevented the attack.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bazzle |first=Steph |title=Judge Says NSA's Data Collection Is Legal |url=http://www.indyposted.com/227717/judge-says-nsas-data-collection-legal/ |publisher=Indyposted |accessdate=28 December 2013 |date=27 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228162843/http://www.indyposted.com/227717/judge-says-nsas-data-collection-legal/ |archivedate=December 28, 2013 }}</ref> U.S. District Judge William H. Pauley III also ruled that Congress legally set up the program and that it does not violate anyone's constitutional rights. The judge also concluded that the telephone data being swept up by NSA did not belong to telephone users, but to the telephone companies. And further he ruled that, when NSA obtains such data from the telephone companies, and then probes into it to find links between callers and potential terrorists, this further use of the data was not even a search under the Fourth Amendment. He also concluded that the controlling precedent is [[Smith v. Maryland]]: "Smith's bedrock holding is that an individual has no legitimate expectation of privacy in information provided to third parties," Judge Pauley wrote.<ref>{{cite news|title=Judge Upholds N.S.A.'s Bulk Collection of Data on Calls|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/28/us/nsa-phone-surveillance-is-lawful-federal-judge-rules.html?ref=us&pagewanted=all|accessdate=28 December 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=27 December 2013|author1=Adam Liptak |author2=Michael S. == Reports == *2009 [[Office of the Inspector General|OIG]] report on [[STELLARWIND]] *Extracts from reports relating to [[XKeyscore]]. One entitled "Tales from the Land of [[Brothers Grimm]]" and others detailing the successes of said software, another is a note from an analyst who felt that he always had one foot in prison when using it. XKeyscore is also described as "big and scary, strong and powerful" and lets an analyst do whatever they like.<ref name =Spiegel3/> *Reports detailing thousands of privacy violations<ref name="WaPo4">{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-broke-privacy-rules-thousands-of-times-per-year-audit-finds/2013/08/15/3310e554-05ca-11e3-a07f-49ddc7417125_story.html|title =NSA broke privacy rules thousands of times per year, audit finds| author=Gellman, Barton|date=August 16, 2013|accessdate=August 16, 2013|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> *Numerous reports relating to drones, including "Threats to Unmanned Aerial Vehicles", a report summarizing attempts to shoot down, intercept, control or otherwise spoof drones. While the report details vulnerabilities of specific aircraft, the document itself has not been published, but only excerpts described. Other reports detail American spin efforts, suggesting that the phrases "drone strike," "kill list," "robot warfare," "Aerial Assassins" be avoided, offering "lethal UAV operations" instead, and also terms like "Pre-emptive and Preventive Military Action" and "Inherent Right of Self Defense." Likewise, reports detail efforts by Al-Qaeda to spin, portraying attacks as cowardly and immoral. Analysts also questioned whether America was losing rhetorical battle in courts, media, and public opinion. Another report stated that drone strikes "could be brought under increased scrutiny, perceived to be illegitimate, openly resisted or undermined."<ref name="wapo20130903">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/us-documents-detail-al-qaedas-efforts-to-fight-back-against-drones/2013/09/03/b83e7654-11c0-11e3-b630-36617ca6640f_story_3.html|title=U.S. documents detail al-Qaeda's efforts to fight back against drones|authors= Craig Whitlock and Barton Gellman|date=September 3, 2013|accessdate=September 3, 2013|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> *The US learned that Pakistan engaged in a pattern of extrajudicial killings, mostly against militants. However, not all targets militants, Pakistan also planned to murder a human rights activist, [[Asma Jahangir]], while she was on a visit to India. The plot was aborted when she learned of it. The US sought to avoid public disclosure of this, and other incidents.<ref name="Wapo20130902">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/top-secret-us-intelligence-files-show-new-levels-of-distrust-of-pakistan/2013/09/02/e19d03c2-11bf-11e3-b630-36617ca6640f_story_3.html|title=Top-secret U.S. intelligence files show new levels of distrust of Pakistan|authors= Greg Miller, Craig Whitlock and Barton Gellman|date=September 2, 2013|accessdate=September 3, 2013|work=The Washington Post}}</ref><!--"cover up" would be the more correct, though less neutral term --><ref name="indiatvnews">{{cite news|url=http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/world/us-intelligence-uncovered-pak-army-plot-to-kill-asma--13317.html|title=US intelligence uncovered Pak army plot to kill Asma Jahangir in India: report|author=Staff|date=September 4, 2013|accessdate=September 4, 2013}}</ref> * The NSA and GCHQ have access to user data in iPhones, BlackBerrys, and Android phones. They are able to read almost all smartphone information, including SMS, location, emails, and notes.<ref name="spiegel20130907">{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/a-920971.html|title= Privacy Scandal: NSA Can Spy on Smart Phone Data|date=September 7, 2013|author=Staff|accessdate=September 7, 2013}}</ref>

== Collection and analysis programs or hardware == *[[Boundless Informant]] – Computer program that physically performs the data collection.<ref>A [[:File:Boundless-heatmap-large-001.jpg|published heat map]] shows that most data is collected from Iran, Pakistan and Jordan, with over 40 billion individual pieces of information collected from these three countries alone in March 2013 alone, from a total of 97 billion worldwide.</ref> *[[Dropmire]] – A program that specifically targets foreign embassies and diplomats *[[XKeyscore]] – A program which allows searching collected data in a variety of ways.<ref name="WaPo5">{{cite news|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/nsa-report-on-privacy-violations-in-the-first-quarter-of-2012/395/|title=NSA report on privacy violations in the first quarter of 2012|date=August 16, 2013|accessdate=August 16, 2013|work=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref name="SMH">[http://www.smh.com.au/world/snowden-reveals-australias-links-to-us-spy-web-20130708-2plyg.html Snowden reveals Australia's links to US spy web], ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', July 8, 2013. Retrieved July 11, 2013.</ref> *[[SHELLTRUMPET]] – A metadata program that targets international communications.<ref name="GuardianShell20130627"/> *[[Unified Targeting Tool]] (UTT) – A graphical frontend for querying databases.<ref name=WaPo5/><ref name="WaPo6">{{cite news|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/what-to-say-and-not-to-say-to-our-overseers/390/|title=What to say, and not to say, to 'our overseers'|date= August 16, 2013|accessdate=August 16, 2013|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> <!--Note: Now there are two screenshots, one shows it's a web based app --> *LOPERS – A software based system to spy on [[Public switched telephone network|PSTN]]s<ref name="SpiegelBoundless1">{{cite web|author=Staff|url=http://www.spiegel.de/fotostrecke/photo-gallery-nsa-documentation-of-spying-in-germany-fotostrecke-99672-4.html|title=Photo Gallery: NSA Documentation of Spying in Germany|date= July 29, 2013|accessdate=August 11, 2013}}</ref> *[[Turbulence (NSA)|TURBULENCE]] – Includes cyber-warfare capabilities, such as targeting enemies with malware. (updates to existing knowledge) *JUGGERNAUT – A system to intercept mobile networks, including voice, fax, data, and text.<ref name=SpiegelBoundless1/> *SPYDER<ref name=WaPo5/> *CHALKFUN<ref name=WaPo5/> *VLR – Visitor Location Register<ref name=WaPo5/> *TransX<ref name=WaPo5/> *[[Ragtime (code name)|RAGTIME]] – A blanket term for any of four different surveillance programs<ref name=WaPo5/><ref name="Barton Gellman and Matt DeLong">{{cite news|title=What to say, and not to say, to 'our overseers'|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/what-to-say-and-not-to-say-to-our-overseers/390/#more|accessdate=August 25, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=August 15, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}</ref> *[[Special Collection Service]] – Joint CIA/NSA eavesdropping team focused based in about 80 US embassies and consulates around the world. There are known branches in Frankfurt and Vienna. According to Der Spiegel, many of their operations are a direct violation of at least 3 signed treaties: "The Convention on the Privileges and Immunities of the United Nations of 1946, the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations of 1961, and a signed an agreement in 1947 that rules out all undercover operations.<ref name=derspiegel20130826/> *[[Stateroom (surveillance program)|STATEROOM]] – Surveillance on embassies and consulates. Highly Classified.<ref name=derspiegel20130826/> * [[Bullrun (code name)|BULLRUN]], named after the [[Second Battle of Bull Run|Battle of Bull Run]]. - Bullrun refers to the NSA's set of codebreaking capabilities, including the use of Computer Network Exploitation (hacking) to obtain keys, weakening of encryption standards and providing backdoors to the same.<ref name="guardian-bullrun">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/05/nsa-gchq-encryption-codes-security | title=US and UK spy agencies defeat privacy and security on the internet | work=The Guardian | date=September 5, 2013 | accessdate=September 5, 2013 |author1=James Ball |author2=Julian Borger |author3=Glenn Greenwald }}</ref> The following codenames are known to be related to BULLRUN: APERIODIC, AMBULANT, AUNTIE, PAINTEDEAGLE, PAWLEYS, PITCHFORD, PENDLETON, PICARESQUE, and PIEDMONT. No further explanation of the above codenames has been provided to date.<ref name="guardian-bullrun-classification">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2013/sep/05/nsa-project-bullrun-classification-guide|title=Project Bullrun – classification guide to the NSA's decryption program|date=September 5, 2013}}</ref> * [[Treasure Map (NSA)|Treasure Map]], near real-time, interactive map of the global Internet. Collects Wi-Fi network and geolocation data, and the traffic of 30-50 million unique Internet addresses. It can reveal the location and owner of a computer, mobile device or router on a daily basis. NSA boasts that the program can map "any device, anywhere, all the time."<ref name="nytimessignt2016">{{cite news|author1=JAMES RISEN |author2=LAURA POITRAS |title=N.S.A. Report Outlined Goals for More Power|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/23/us/politics/nsa-report-outlined-goals-for-more-power.html|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|accessdate=23 November 2013|date=November 22, 2013}}</ref>

== GCHQ operations == {{Main |Government Communications Headquarters |Mass surveillance in the United Kingdom}} <!-- [[File:GCHQ TURMOIL.svg|thumb|right|TURMOIL, an NSA program, using hardware acceleration for decryption, which is accessible to the "Five Eyes" nations. The Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ) is the main British [[intelligence agency]] responsible for providing [[signals intelligence]] (SIGINT) and [[information assurance]] to the [[Her Majesty's Government|British government]] and [[British Armed Forces|armed forces]]. *[[Tempora]] – Collects data from transatlantic fibre-optic cables of major telecommunications corporations by directly tapping on them and from Internet backbones. Tempora uses intercepts on the fibre-optic cables that make up the backbone of the internet to gain access to swaths of internet users' personal data. The intercepts are placed in the United Kingdom and overseas, with the knowledge of companies owning either the cables or landing stations. It is a GCHQ program to create a large-scale "Internet buffer" which stores Internet content for three days and metadata for up to 30 days.<ref name="upstream" /><ref name="Tempora20131025">{{cite news|last=Ball|first=James|title=Leaked memos reveal GCHQ efforts to keep mass surveillance secret|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/oct/25/leaked-memos-gchq-mass-surveillance-secret-snowden|accessdate=October 25, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=October 25, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Revealed: how US and UK spy agencies defeat internet privacy and security|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/05/nsa-gchq-encryption-codes-security|accessdate=September 7, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=September 6, 2013|author1=James Ball |author2=Julian Borger |author3=Glenn Greenwald }}</ref> Its component programs are [[Mastering the Internet]] and [[Global Telecoms Exploitation]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Mastering the internet: how GCHQ set out to spy on the world wide web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/jun/21/gchq-mastering-the-internet|accessdate=18 December 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=21 June 2013}}</ref> *[[Karma Police (surveillance program)|Karma Police]] - Internet metadata collection program designed to profile the web browsing habits of 'every visible user on the Internet'.<ref>url=https://theintercept.com/2015/09/25/gchq-radio-porn-spies-track-web-users-online-identities/</ref> *Britain runs a large-scale intercept station in the Middle East, capable of tapping underwater fiber-optic cables and satellites, and extracting email, telephone, and web traffic. The information is then passed to the GCHQ and shared with the NSA. The operation costs around £1 billion and is still being assembled. It is part of the "Tempora" project.<ref name="independent1">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/exclusive-edward-snowden-leaks-reveal-uks-secret-middleeast-web-surveillance-base-8781082.html|title=Exclusive: Edward Snowden leaks reveal UK's secret Middle-East web surveillance base|authors = Duncan Campbell, Oliver Wright, James Cusick, Kim Sengupta|date=August 22, 2013|accessdate=August 22, 2013|location=London|work=The Independent}}</ref> Edward Snowden disputes the Independent's claim that he, or anyone he has had direct contact with is the source of this information.<ref name="Guardian7">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/aug/23/uk-government-independent-military-base|title=Snowden: UK government now leaking documents about itself|author=Greenwald, Glenn|date=August 23, 2013|accessdate=August 23, 2013}}</ref> ''[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]'''s fiber optic revelations were also described as having been obtained from GC-Wiki by Snowden.<ref name="SZAug28">{{cite news|url=http://international.sueddeutsche.de/post/59603415442/british-officials-have-far-reaching-access-to-internet|title=British Officials Have Far-Reaching Access To Internet And Telephone Communications|author1=John Goetz |author2=Hans Leyendecker |author3=Frederik Obermaier |date=August 28, 2013|accessdate=August 28, 2013}}</ref> *GCHQ is believed to have forced some six global telecommunications and Internet companies to allow them to access more than 14 fiber optic cables that transport telephone communications.<ref name=SZAug28/> The six companies, [[BT Group|BT]], [[Vodafone]], [[Viatel]], [[Interoute]], [[Verizon]] and Level-3, gave GCHQ access to the cables in return for payment, it is believed the companies had no choice in this decision.<ref name=SZAug28/> Three of the cables' terminal stations are on German territory; == Suggested protective measures from surveillance ==
=== Encryption === In [[cryptography]], [[encryption]] is the process of encoding information in such a way that eavesdroppers or hackers cannot read it, but that authorized parties can. According to Snowden's recommendations published by ''The Guardian Edward'' in September 2013,<ref name="Encryp" /> properly implemented strong [[Cryptosystem|crypto systems]] were among the few things which one can rely on. However, [[Communication endpoint|endpoint]] security is often too weak to prevent the [[NSA]] from finding ways around it.<ref name="Encryp">{{cite web|title=NSA surveillance: A guide to staying secure|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/05/nsa-how-to-remain-secure-surveillance|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|accessdate=September 24, 2013}}</ref>
=== Underground bunkers === In September 2013, it was reported by the press that a number of countries deemed by the US and its allies to be [[rogue state]]s, such as [[Syria]], [[Iran]] and [[North Korea]], had successfully evaded U.S. government surveillance by constructing secret bunkers deep below the Earth's surface.<ref name="thehindu">{{cite news|last=Narayan Lakshman|title=Secret bunkers, a challenge for U.S. intelligence|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/world/secret-bunkers-a-challenge-for-us-intelligence/article5164833.ece?ref=relatedNews|publisher=''[[The Hindu]]''|accessdate=September 24, 2013|location=Chennai, India|date=September 24, 2013}}</ref>
[[China]]'s underground megaproject, the [[816 Nuclear Military Plant]] in [[Chongqing]] (now declassified and opened to tourists), was reported to be "most worrying" for the U.S. [[Defense Intelligence Agency]].<ref name="thehindu"/>
[[Libya]] evaded surveillance by building "hardened and buried" bunkers at least 40 feet below ground level.<ref name="thehindu"/>

The '''ITF Rankings''' are the current rankings of national teams by the [[International Tennis Federation]] in both men's and women's [[tennis]]. The ITF produces two sets of rankings—the ITF [[Davis Cup]] Nations Ranking for male national teams, and the ITF [[Fed Cup]] Nations Ranking for female national teams. Both sets of rankings measure the success of all nations participating in both competitions.
The ITF Davis Cup Nations Ranking was launched at the end of 2001 and the ITF Fed Cup Nations Ranking was introduced a year later. Both rankings are updated following every World Group round and are used for [[seed (sports)|seeding]] the highest ranked teams in the draws for each group in the competitions' structures.
==Ranking method==
The ITF [[Davis Cup]] and [[Fed Cup]] rankings are based in a rolling four year cumulative system. However, the points total for each nation is calculated following a weighted sum formula, in which recent results are weighted more heavily.<ref name="ITFDavisCupRankingsExplained">{{cite web|work=daviscup.com|publisher=International Tennis Federation|title=Rankings Explained| url = http://www.daviscup.com/en/rankings/rankings-explained.aspx}}</ref><ref name="ITFFedCupRankingsExplained">{{cite web|work=fedcup.com|publisher=International Tennis Federation|title=How the Rankings Work| url = http://www.fedcup.com/en/rankings/rankings-explained.aspx}}</ref> After each World Group round, the ranking period adjusts, and points earned in the last year period have a weighting factor of 100% in the points total. At the same time, the weighting factor for the points earned until the same round in the previous three years is reduced to 75% (for points earned one to two years ago), 50% (for points earned two to three years ago) and 25% (for points earned three to four years ago).
Ranking points are awarded only to the winning nation of a competition tie at every round. Victories in World Group rounds are worth more points than those in Zone Groups, and ties at the later rounds of the competition are progressively worth more points. Bonus points are also awarded for a nation that defeats a higher-ranked nation, but only if the latter nation is ranked in the top 64 for the Davis Cup, or in the top 75 for the Fed Cup. Unique to the Davis Cup, there is an additional bonus for a nation that wins a tie in the opponent's home ground: a 25% bonus is added to the total of round points and ranking bonus points (if any). At the Fed Cup only, nations that win by walkover are awarded round points but no bonus points, and no points are awarded for consolation events.
